<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 396, 218, 412]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 412, 839, 604]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 632, 208, 647]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 648, 693, 679]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 68, 89, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 67, 876, 129]]<|/det|>
Farmer \(A\) grows apples of a certain variety. Each tree produces \(14.8\mathrm{kg}\) of apples, on average, per year. Farmer \(B\) grows apples of the same variety and claims that his apple trees produce a higher mass of apples per year than Farmer \(A\)'s trees. The masses of apples from Farmer \(B\)'s trees may be assumed to be normally distributed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 138, 876, 170]]<|/det|>
A random sample of 10 trees from Farmer \(B\) is chosen. The masses, \(x \mathrm{kg}\), of apples produced in a year are summarised as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[356, 178, 593, 198]]<|/det|>
\[\Sigma x = 152.0\qquad \Sigma x^2 = 2313.0\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 207, 876, 225]]<|/det|>
Test, at the \(5\%\) significance level, whether Farmer \(B\)'s claim is justified. [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[860, 207, 878, 225]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 68, 91, 85]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 67, 875, 117]]<|/det|> A company is developing a new flavour of chocolate by varying the quantities of the ingredients. A random selection of 9 flavours of chocolate are judged by two tasters who each give marks out of 100 to each flavour of chocolate. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 127, 875, 201]]<|/det|>
ChocolateABCDEFGHI
Taster 1728675929879876062
Taster 2847274958587827568
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 217, 875, 250]]<|/det|> Carry out a Wilcoxon matched-pairs signed-rank test at the \(10\%\) significance level to investigate whether, on average, there is a difference between marks awarded by the two tasters. [7] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 900, 161, 915]]<|/det|> © UCLES 2021 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 900, 515, 915]]<|/det|> 9231/43/M/J/21 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 900, 875, 915]]<|/det|> [Turn over

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 68, 89, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 67, 875, 115]]<|/det|>
The heights, \(x \mathrm{m}\), of a random sample of 50 adult males from country \(A\) were recorded. The heights, \(y \mathrm{m}\), of a random sample of 40 adult males from country \(B\) were also recorded. The results are summarised as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 125, 719, 144]]<|/det|>
\[\Sigma x = 89.0\qquad \Sigma x^{2} = 159.4\qquad \Sigma y = 67.2\qquad \Sigma y^{2} = 113.1\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 156, 875, 189]]<|/det|>
Find a \(95\%\) confidence interval for the difference between the mean heights of adult males from country \(A\) and adult males from country \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 170, 875, 188]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[69, 900, 161, 914]]<|/det|>
© UCLES 2021

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 900, 517, 912]]<|/det|>
9231/43/M/J/21

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 68, 89, 87]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 67, 875, 131]]<|/det|> Chai packs china mugs into cardboard boxes. Chai's manager suspects that breakages occur at random times and that the number of breakages may follow a Poisson distribution. He takes a small sample of observations and finds that the number of breakages in a one-hour period has a mean of 2.4 and a standard deviation of 1.5. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 141, 138, 159]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 141, 680, 160]]<|/det|> Explain how this information tends to support the manager's suspicion. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 141, 876, 160]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 170, 875, 191]]<|/det|>
...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 203, 873, 222]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 235, 873, 253]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 266, 873, 285]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 298, 873, 317]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 330, 873, 348]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 361, 873, 380]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 393, 873, 411]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 465, 876, 515]]<|/det|> The manager now takes a larger sample and claims that the numbers of breakages in a one-hour period follow a Poisson distribution. The numbers of breakages in a random sample of 180 one-hour periods are summarised in the following table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 523, 856, 575]]<|/det|>
Number of breakages01234567 or more
Frequency213346312316100
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 591, 606, 610]]<|/det|> The mean number of breakages calculated from this sample is 2.5. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 621, 141, 640]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 621, 876, 655]]<|/det|> Use the data from this larger sample to carry out a goodness of fit test, at the \(10\%\) significance level, to test the claim. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 636, 876, 655]]<|/det|> [8] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 897, 161, 912]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 897, 218, 912]]<|/det|> UCLES 2021 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 897, 518, 912]]<|/det|> 9231/43/M/J/21

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 68, 92, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 67, 690, 87]]<|/det|>
The continuous random variable \(X\) has probability density function f given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[326, 101, 625, 163]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \begin{cases} \frac{1}{8} & 0\leqslant x< 1,\\ \frac{1}{28} (8 - x) & 1\leqslant x\leqslant 8,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}. \end{cases}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 185, 139, 203]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 185, 495, 203]]<|/det|>
Find the cumulative distribution function of \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 185, 876, 203]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 504, 176, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[181, 504, 569, 523]]<|/det|>
Find the value of the constant \(a\) such that \(\mathrm{P}(X \leqslant a) = \frac{5}{7}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 505, 876, 523]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
